comments.commentBody: Like Frank Rich mentioned in his recent column, 1% of Americans collect 25% of the total pay in America.  How is this far or right?  The economic machinations of Goldman Sachs and other companies of the same ilk have brought America to its knees and millions have suffered because of it.

What a strange world we live in.  Teachers have to spend from their meager salaries to buy chalk, and partners at Goldman Sachs essentially get compensated truly obscene amounts of money for producing: what?  Exotic instruments that exist in a netherworld of legal language and prospectuses, but which cannot be touched, held, or truly accounted for in a meaningful way?  Fancy, lucrative snake oil.  The institutional arrogance is astounding--why, as a culture, do we (or did we) honor this so?

There is no such thing as a partner in a corporation. Partners disappeared at the IPO. This is just a ploy to get these idiots to work harder for Goldman shareholders. “To have it taken away would just be devastating to an individual. There is just no other word for it.” What type of individual would be devasted by having a fake title taken away? Probably the same type of individual too pathetic to notice problems in the credit markets. Honestly, do you think someone like Warren Buffet would even care about the view from his window. Newsflash to Goldman employees... make a couple of $ million and get out before you start acting like these mutants and believing this BS. You will be a lot happier, trust me. No one is impressed except business school students. A couple of $ million is all you need then find a real interesting job and try to spend time with your family and you'll be happy.

comments.userLocation: In the castle of my skin
comments.commentBody:
Several of those 17 McNabb incompletions were flat out drops by the Redskins receivers, including what was a bobbled surefire touchdown with the Skins up 10-0. That series ended with a botched snap on a FG try. Some of the same things that drove Eagles fans crazy were evident in this game as well... balls sailing over the heads of receivers, balls in the dirt... late passes. Not sure how much of that was on McNabb or how much was lack of chemistry with a new receiving corps.

Gotta feel bad for Leonard Weaver... hardworking guy, really sorry to see that happen to anyone, let alone a "nice guy".

I for one will be very glad to see Roger ride off into the sunset. The worship of him has been and is completely over the top and has smothered so much of what is good in the game of tennis. For instance, your statement that the Fed/Djokovic match was the best of the tournament. Hello? Yes, the last half of the fifth set was tense and exciting but c'mon, did you watch the Ferrer/Verdasco match? The Murray/Wawrinka match? There have been some terrific games but the media is so Federer centric the rest of the tennis world suffers. Hopefully now that his time has come and gone, some attention will be paid to some other fantastic tennis players and the game of tennis will be better for it.

#16, the RF branding all over the place is to do with Federer's Foundation helping kids get an education all over Africa - people buying all the RF gear contribute to that. I agree his clothes at Wimbledon last year were over the top and thank god he toned it down this year, but at least give him credit for being passionate about his work in Africa. I hope he retires soon and devotes himself to this, as he says he's going to. I think he's had it on court, so he might as well. Nothing worse than seeing a champ start to fade.

To me political parties mean veyr little in this current age.  Not because I am an independent, but because the two parties are so general and broad that they cannot even make positions on specific issues without inner-party argument.  In Europe where they have a mutlitude of well-defined parties it is easier for a politician to chose a party.  Here, in the U.S., it is really either Republican or Democrat.  Everyone to the right tends to go to republican and the others go democrat.  Democrats vote conservative all the time and republicans can sometimes be counted on to vote liberal on social issues or centrist at least.  There is no reason for someone to be ashamed of their party because the parties mean absolutely nothing.  The republican party is no the same as the free-soilers who founded it the democrats do not govern in jeffersonian and jacksonian manners.  It unfortunate there cannot be more parties so that maybe fiscally conservative socially liberal voters could have a pary or vice-versa.  So that blue-dogs have a party of their own and so that libertarians do to.  But for now it is between democrat and republican and the name should mean nothing.

This is why the Democrats get trounced and look life wafflers day in day out: they can't stick together. What in the world are four Dem. Senators doing talking about extending the top-tier tax cuts? Even if they are wrong, the Republicans still show the appearance of backbone through unity. They's get more respect if they could figure this out. And take the leadership from Las Vegas and San Francisco of all places.

Well why not? The circular firing squad has always worked for them before!? This is the same type of thinking that lead to Al Gore's failure to achieve a decisive win in 2000 and the same type of thinking that has landed President Obama such a sad political state : Work from a position of weakness and trade your best cards to the dealer.

Democrats who 'shy away' from their own party are falling for the prevailing media/right spin that a small faction of the most vocal public is falling for, contrary to their own self-interest.

Democrats!!!! Step up and be counted, for cryin' out loud!
The Republicans don't have to run against Mr. Obama anymore.  They need only run against Austen Goolsbee.
They are shying from their own party because they know the people know what they are up to and don't trust them anymore.

The NY Times, first class newspaper that it is, is just noticing this?

Not advertising a party affiliation has been going on for at least 3 (national) election cycles and it happens on both sides of the isle. This phenomena is especially true when a politician is running in a area not favorable to the overall leaning of their party. It is also seems to be very true with incumbents who have already won in an area not favorable to their over all party leanings but are ruining again. Their advertisements have no identification but make it clear they are incumbents (i.e.: it's o.k. He/she is one of us.)

Again, this has been happening for at least 3 (national) election cycles. NY Times! Get with the program. At least report the news from this election cycle, not 3 cycles ago.

I'm not sure that Robin Carnahan needs to advertise that she's a Democrat or that Roy Blunt's a Republican. Carnahan's father was a two-term governor who beat John Ashcroft for the U.S. Senate seat in 2000, even though he was killed in a plane crash 2 or 3 weeks before the election; her mother then took the seat. Her brother is a Congressman. Roy Blunt's been in Congress for years, and before that was Secretary of State. His son was a one-term governor.

Of course, Missourians who pay attention to these things probably already know how they're going to vote.

The Democratic party is pathetic.  Rather than stand on principle, its candidates hide under the table, fearful that they might be identified as radicals, and therefore, in the present climate, as un-American and perhaps communists.  What has happened to America?  I lived through McCarthyism, but now is far worse: a wholesale capitulation to the Right, in which President Obama, whose policies are in fact well right-of-center, appears even to fellow Democrats as a grave danger to the nation.  What of financial regulation that gives the banking and hedge-fund communities everything they want?  What of health-care legislation that is a boon to the insurance and pharmaceutical industries?  What of job creation, which is practically nonexistent, or escalation in Afghanistan, or national-security ideology and practice run amuck?  In sum, the Democratic record, from the president and his cabinet on down, is a travesty, a profound disgrace, as measured by Obama's campaign promises--and yet Democratic candidates pedal faster and faster to the Right to appease the very interests they pretend to oppose.

My husband and I decided to change our party affiliation from Democratic to unaffiliated because of Democratic Party has lost its soul. I could never align myself with the right-wing, fanatical racists that seem to make up the Republican Party these days, and I never thought I'd abandon the Democratic Party. I can no longer support a party that has abandoned its Democratic president and has stood mutely by as religious and racial intolerance has swept the nation.

I consistently vote Democratic. I have done so for a lifetime. In 2008, I voted for Barack Obama and the respective Democratic candidates for the Senate and for Congress. In so doing, I wasn't voting for a right-wing agenda. Contrary to much commentary on these New York Times pages, I think that Obama has been an articulate advocate for Democratic platform and its related legislative achievements. Rather than cowering with tails between their legs Democratic candidates should be out proclaiming their program as loudly as their vociferous opponents on the right. If the Party's candidates are so spineless as to run away from their own actions, then they deserve to lose. Heaven help the Union if the Democratic Congress becomes the architect of its own defeat. Grow some grapes, Democrats, and celebrate what you believe!

I'm proud of President Obama's accomplishments, and Democrats who shy from ties to their own party should get out of the race and let real Democrats run.

1. Ordered all federal agencies to undertake a study and make recommendations for ways to cut spending.

2. Negotiated deal with Swiss banks to permit US government to gain access to records of tax evaders.

3. Shut down offshore tax safe havens.

4. Ended the previous policy of offering tax benefits to corporations who outsource American jobs.

5. Ended the practice of protecting credit card companies; in place of it are new consumer and small business protections from credit card industry’s predatory practices and excessive surcharges.

6. Enforced equal pay for women with his first legislative act - the Lilly Ledbetter Act.

7. Cover expenses of families of fallen soldiers so they may be on hand when the body arrives at Dover AFB.

8. Improved housing for military personnel and initiated a new policy to promote federal hiring of military spouses.

9. Improved conditions at Walter Reed Military Hospital and other military hospitals.

10. Improved Veteran’s Benefits.

11. Ended the previous stop-loss policy that kept soldiers doing tour after tour after tour of duty in Iraq and Afghanistan longer than their enlistment date.

12. Better body armor is now being provided to our troops.

13. Authorized construction/opening of additional health centers to care for veterans..

14. Lowered federal income tax for the middle class. ( was at its lowest in 60 years when the Tea Party rallied on April 15.)

15. The White House and federal government are again respecting the Freedom of Information Act again (it was ignored during GW Bush’s eight years).

16. Instructed all federal agencies to promote openness and transparency as much as possible.

17. Limited lobbyist’s access to the White House.

18. Phased out the expensive F-22 war plane and other outmoded weapons systems that weren’t even used or needed in Iraq/Afghanistan, thereby saving the country billions.

The cost of production of ONLY ONE F-22 was around $138 MILLION.

19. The missile defense program this year alone is getting trimmed to the tune of $1.4 billion in saving in 2010.

20. Federal support of life-saving biomedical research.

21. Instituted a new focus on mortgage fraud.

22. Housing rescue plan, thereby keeping families from losing their homes if they are having trouble paying.

23. Restarted the nuclear nonproliferation talks and building back up the nuclear inspection infrastructure/protocols.

24. The secret detention facilities in Eastern Europe and elsewhere are being closed.

25. The USA is once again in compliance with the Geneva Convention standards, which not only restores our integrity and standing, but also helps our soldiers.

26. Ended previous policy of awarding no-bid defense contracts.

27. Visited more countries and met with more world leaders than any president in his first six months in office.

28. Sent envoys to Middle East and other parts of the world that had been neglected for years; re engaging in multilateral and bilateral talks and diplomacy.

29. Made more loans available to small businesses through community banks.

30. Increased and improved student loans.

31. High-speed broadband Internet access to K-12 schools.

32. Expansion the SCHIP program to cover health care for 4 million more children.

33. Expanded national youth service program.

34. Ended the previous practice of forbidding Medicare from negotiating with drug manufacturers for less expensive drugs and lowered prescription drug costs for senior citizens.

35. Re-engaged our country to discuss climate change, greenhouse gas emissions, and green technology.

34. Ended previous practice of having White House aides rewrite scientific rules, regulations, and reports.

35. Our nation’s healthcare system - which was the most expensive in the world while leaving 50 million without health insurance and millions more under-insured as insurance companies were able to double their rates, cap benefits, and deny claims - is finally on its way to catching up with affordable health care available to citizens of every other industrialized nation.

36. Appointed Michael R. Bromwich, a former Assistant U.S. Attorney and Justice Department Inspector General, to head the MMS, to reorganize and to eliminate conflicts. (Before his appointment as Inspector General, Mr. Bromwich served as a federal prosecutor in the U.S. Attorney’s Office for the Southern District of New York and as Associate Counsel in the Office of Independent Counsel for Iran-Contra scandal investigation.)

37. Refutes the Republicans' sick contention that the Bush Tax Cuts should become permanent.

There are more but there's not enough room in my comments section.

TO THE DEMOCRATS CAMPAIGNING - WE VOTED FOR PRESIDENT OBAMA AND STILL BACK HIM.
Got spine?

Too bad Dems can't/won't just tell the truth:
1) I cleaned up the mess the Repupicants made of useless and unwinnable wars and an economic system teetering on the brink.
2) I made health care available to many more people and kept insurance companies from canceling policies and keeping kids from being insured.
3) I will retain social social security.
4) I will vote to help small businesses.
5) I will help middle class families.
6) I will help put people back to work.
7) I will ask the rich to give a fairer share.
8) My opponent didn't or won't--for all of the above.

One hopes that not only will the truth set us free but get right-minded people elected.

Democrats, Timid, Timorous & Tentative; But Why?
http://www.nigeriavillagesquare.com...

All through the preceding 15 months, Obama allowed and the Democrats were sleepily complacent, and in that vacuum default position by the Democrats, Republicans and their surrogates and proxies in Tea Party , adversaries, to frame the issues or hijacked American national issues and narratives; And as a consequence, the American electorate have been indoctrinated to see Obama Care as profanities and expletives and Grandma Death Panels became the ultimate obscenity core pornographic voyeuristic expression. Senator John Kerry, similarly allowed the Bush Campaign to define him in 2004, Senator Kerry, a war hero was given a downward definition, and Mr. Bush who actually evaded or dodged the Draft or conscription for war in Vietnam, came out smelling like roses and strong on national security.

And now, in eerie resemblance-recurrence, and with roughly 50 days to midterm elections, some Democrats are campaigning against their party policies, in trepidation of seething electorate, enraged and made dangerous and potent weapons against the Democrats by the Republicans, who have put Americans, as Mr. Obama rightly put it, in the ditch, through recklessness. Democrats are now even afraid of the S word also known as Stimulus! But why? Just because Republicans are now against everything the Democrats stand for and the Republicans even use to stand for? Are the Democrats spineless? We know that the American economy can use another stimulus package, to help generate jobs in this jobless recovery. Another stimulus package geared toward public infrastructures renewals, expansions and rehabilitation. Why are Democrats now afraid to even mention Stimulus Package now? Oh, yes, Republicans spendthrifts during the last 8 years, are suddenly self advertised as deficit hawks and Democrats are suckered?

Why can’t Obama and the Democrats find the audacity to mock Republicans’ wrongheaded prescriptions for the economy? Tax Cuts for the rich, the rich who currently, are not investing now and not hiring. Republicans prescribe, on the other hand, Freezes on Spending, and both prescriptions are silly, and are contrary to what most American economist recommend, particularly so, in view of the fact that the economic dire strait in America, was brought about by the Republican Party, with George W. Bush in the White House, the time Americans were plunged America this economic recession-depression.
Why does the media continue to incite fear?  Don't the Republican right wing do enough of it, such as fraud snooze.

"Democratic candidates are not extolling their party’s accomplishments, but rather distancing themselves from their party’s agenda."

What a mistake. That's the very mistake Al Gore made in 2000.

Well, it's deja vu all over again. The strategies of "shying from one's own party" is a variant of the moderate and conservative Democrats in 1994, and we know how that turned out. Despite that no-nothing's ranting, Rush Limbaugh was wrong when he declared the Republican victory a rout of the liberals, because not one liberal lost their election. Who did lose were those unfortunate examples of the Democratic Party who tried to out Republican the Republicans, and who backed away from association with Clinton. If they want to win, they must stand up for the progressive positions of the party, demand that Obama do more for Main Street instead of Wall Street, and point out the Republicans have no ideas other than a return to the policies that got us into this mess. In other words, get a BACK BONE or else start practicing: "Would you like fries with your order."

I strongly prefer our Democratic candidate for Senate, but I'm afraid to vote for him.  I can't take the chance that he'll further Obama's dangerous agenda. (I voted for Obama, but I regret it.)  I'll be holding my nose and voting for a Republican I really don't like.
